title: Murdoch's 21st Century Fox Positioned for 25% Spike
text:
Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Twenty-First Century Fox ( FOX - Get Report ) ( FOXA - Get Report ) is poised to spike up to 25% on increasingly large fees from network affiliates across the country, Bernstein media analyst Todd Juenger said in an investor note on Friday. 
"While we are pessimists on advertising , we are optimists on affiliate fees and international, and FOXA has arguably the strongest affiliate fee pricing power in the U.S. and, along with Discovery DISCA, the best international platform," Juenger said in a note Friday, reiterating the firm's outperform rating. 
FOX is down 9.2% year-to-date, having closed at $33.47 Thursday, and down 3.0% over the past year. FOXA is off 10.8% year-to-date, having closed at $34.25 Thursday, and down 3.9% over the past year. The company is scheduled to release fourth-quarter earnings August 5. 
Last year, Bernstein also projected impressive upsides for Twenty-First Century Fox , however shares traded essentially flat. Now, analysts are expecting 0% downside with a roughly 25% upside, calling for fiscal year 2016 EBITDA of $7 billion. If Fox's results meet fiscal 2017 EBITDA expectations, the stock would likely hit $42 per share in a year, also boosted by expected growth in international cable, Juenger projects. 
Must Read: 10 Stocks George Soros Is Buying 
Juenger said he has "confidence" in the higher valuation, with political coverage and Super Bowl coverage expected to help boost affiliate fees and retransmission fees that would more than offset declines in advertising. Bernstein's advertising forecast calls for a low- to mid-single-digit declines for broadcast and low-to mid-single-digit increases for cable. TV segment ad revenues are expected to decline at low-to mid-single-digits through fiscal 2017, "fading to low-singles in perpetuity." 
Further contributing to Fox's upside potential, the media company has several equity interests that haven't been fully realized, namely its 39% stake in Sky ( SKYAY ) , its 50% investment in Endemol Shine , 33% stake in Hulu , and its 30% interest in Indian DBS company Tata Sky . 
"All have received public valuation marks of late, most of which are not reflected in Fox's current book value of investments," Juenger wrote. 
Recently, Fox, which aired the FIFA Women's World Cup 2015 finals, in which the U.S. defeated Japan 5-2, scored an unexpectedly large audience in the final game July 5. More than 25 million viewers tuned in, making it the most watched soccer game, men's or women's, of all time on a U.S network. This article is commentary by an independent contributor.
